title: Consett and Sunderland Railway Path Walking Route

nearby.description: Pow Hill Country Park and Derwent Reservoir

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Consett and Sunderland cycle path
images.caption: The Consett and Sunderland railway path is a component of the C2C cycle route, and carries large numbers of recreational cyclists throughout the year. The section pictured here runs between Lydgett Junction and the Consett By-pass

images.title: Ann Hodgson / Sculptures on the Consett and Sunderland Railway path.
images.caption: Sculptures on the path

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Consett and Sunderland Railway Path at Stanley
images.caption: NCN Millennium Milepost at Stanley, County Durham

images.title: Oliver Dixon / "The ravines" at New Kyo
images.caption: "The ravines" at New Kyo. "The ravines" are a series of artistic earthworks which form an interesting obstacle on the Consett and Sunderland railway path (part of the C2C Cycle Route)

images.title: Oliver Dixon / The Lambton Worm
images.caption: The Lambton Worm. This sinuous earthwork, designed by Andy Goldsworthy, commemorates the local mythical beast "the Lambton Worm".

images.title: Oliver Dixon / One of the Beamish shorthorns
images.caption: Shorthorn cattle sculpture at Beamish, County Durham. Built by Sally Matthews, the Beamish Shorthorns, constructed from scrap metal contentedly graze by the side of the trail. A group of cyclists can be seen admiring the piece.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Jolly Drover's Roundabout, Leadgate
images.caption: Jolly Drover's Roundabout, Leadgate. This roundabout on the A692 is traversed at this point by the Consett and Sunderland railway path on the C2C cycle route. In the middle ground, to the left, although not clear on this photograph, is "the Maze" a complex earthworks by Andy Goldsworthy, through which the cycle path wends its way.

images.title: Oliver Dixon, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Crucible on the C2C. This relic of the once mighty steelworks at Consett marks the spot where four railway paths meet - the Waskerley Way from Stanhope Moor, the Consett and Sunderland path, the Derwent Valley Path down to Gateshead and the Lanchester Path down to Durham.

description: A walk or cycle along a disused railway path from Consett to Sunderland. The path starts at Consett and heads east towards the coast passing Stanley and Chester-le-Street before joining the River Wear and following it to Sunderland harbour.  You'll also pass Beamish Woods where there's some nice woodland trails and the views of the River Team. It's a fairly flat surfaced path with a number of sculptures, interesting earthworks and fine views of the Durham countryside to enjoy.
